body:
As for the signature, in `torch/jit/__init__.py` I wrapped `torch._C.get_tracing_state`, so that it's accessible as `torch.jit.get_tracing_state`. I chose to expand the `*args` from the former in the signature of the latter, since this is an operation that the user would have to do frequently when pushing and popping.

As to `flatten` vs `_first_var`: `get_tracing_state` needs at least one variable, so I just stop at the first I find. Is there an advantage with using more than one? Maybe we should check that the variable we encounter is traced at all?

As to flatten vs _first_var: get_tracing_state needs at least one variable, so I just stop at the first I find. Is there an advantage with using more than one? Maybe we should check that the variable we encounter is traced at all?
body_text:
As for the signature, in torch/jit/__init__.py I wrapped torch._C.get_tracing_state, so that it's accessible as torch.jit.get_tracing_state. I chose to expand the *args from the former in the signature of the latter, since this is an operation that the user would have to do frequently when pushing and popping.
As to flatten vs _first_var: get_tracing_state needs at least one variable, so I just stop at the first I find. Is there an advantage with using more than one? Maybe we should check that the variable we encounter is traced at all?
